user_message:
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified. Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. Here is the code of iterate_post: ```c static enum MHD_Result iterate_post (void *coninfo_cls, enum MHD_ValueKind kind, const char *key, const char *filename, const char *content_type, const char *transfer_encoding, const char *data, uint64_t off, size_t size) { struct connection_info_struct *con_info = coninfo_cls; (void) kind; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */ (void) filename; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */ (void) content_type; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */ (void) transfer_encoding; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */ (void) off; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */ if (0 == strcmp (key, "name")) { if ((size > 0) && (size <= MAXNAMESIZE)) { char *answerstring; answerstring = malloc (MAXANSWERSIZE); if (! answerstring) return MHD_NO; snprintf (answerstring, MAXANSWERSIZE, GREETINGPAGE, data); con_info->answerstring = answerstring; } else con_info->answerstring = NULL; return MHD_NO; } return MHD_YES; } ``` Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function iterate_post: struct connection_info_struct { int connectiontype; char *answerstring; struct MHD_PostProcessor *postprocessor; } ... #define MAXNAMESIZE 20 ... #define MAXANSWERSIZE 512 ... #define GREETINGPAGE "

Welcome, %s!

" ... enum MHD_Result { /** * MHD result code for "NO". */ MHD_NO = 0, /** * MHD result code for "YES". */ MHD_YES = 1 } ... enum MHD_ValueKind { /** * Response header * @deprecated */ MHD_RESPONSE_HEADER_KIND = 0, #define MHD_RESPONSE_HEADER_KIND \ _MHD_DEPR_IN_MACRO ( \ "Value MHD_RESPONSE_HEADER_KIND is deprecated and not used") \ MHD_RESPONSE_HEADER_KIND /** * HTTP header (request/response). */ MHD_HEADER_KIND = 1, /** * Cookies. Note that the original HTTP header containing * the cookie(s) will still be available and intact. */ MHD_COOKIE_KIND = 2, /** * POST data. This is available only if a content encoding * supported by MHD is used (currently only URL encoding), * and only if the posted content fits within the available * memory pool. Note that in that case, the upload data * given to the #MHD_AccessHandlerCallback will be * empty (since it has already been processed). */ MHD_POSTDATA_KIND = 4, /** * GET (URI) arguments. */ MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND = 8, /** * HTTP footer (only for HTTP 1.1 chunked encodings). */ MHD_FOOTER_KIND = 16 } Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter variable is modified in the body of iterate_post. The parameters kind, filename, content_type, transfer_encoding and off are explicitly marked unused via (void) casts and therefore not modified. The pointer parameter coninfo_cls is not reassigned; it is read and cast into a local pointer variable (struct connection_info_struct *con_info = coninfo_cls), which does not modify the parameter itself. Only the object pointed to by that pointer (con_info->answerstring) is written to or set to NULL — modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by MISRA C Rule 17.8. Other parameters (key, data, size) are only read (e.g. strcmp, snprintf) and not assigned to. Therefore there are no fragments that violate Rule 17.8 and nothing else needs investigation for this rule.
